Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Experimental Studies of Dilute Pyroclastic Density Currents
Award.AbstractNarration:
Pyroclastic density currents are hot and fast-moving mixtures of solid particles and gas produced by explosive volcanic eruptions or the collapse of lava domes. They travel great distances, pose substantial hazards, and alter landscapes. The processes governing the movement of, and transport in, pyroclastic density currents are not well understood quantitatively. Even conceptual models remain controversial. Basic questions remain about how hills, ridges, and valleys alter and direct pyroclastic density currents and about how air mixes into the currents. These key processes control current speed, direction, and injection of ash into the atmosphere. The long term outcome of better understanding pyroclastic density currents is a scientific foundation for assessing the hazards they pose.

This project will use dynamically scaled laboratory experiments, in particular their interaction with topography, to understand pyroclastic density current dynamics. This will be accomplished by imaging the three-dimensional velocity and concentration fields inside modeled dilute pyroclastic density currents, and quantifying the entrainment of air and sedimentation of particles. This understanding will improve our ability to relate field deposits to the dynamics of these currents. The experimental setup is designed to permit a large number of experiments and hence to explore relationships between parameters and processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pyroclastic density currents are hot and fast-moving mixtures of solid particles and gas produced by explosive volcanic eruptions or the collapse of lava domes. They travel great distances, pose substantial hazards, and alter landscapes. The processes governing the propagation motion of, and transport within, pyroclastic density currents are not well understood quantitatively.

 

This project used dynamically scaled laboratory experiments, numerical models,  and field deposits, to better understand their pyroclastic density current dynamics. We quantified how density currents can entrain the material over which they travel and how this increases the distance they travel. We determined experimentally the concentration of particles in density currents. We further quantified how density currents interact with topography and the height of barriers that they can surmount. Our laboratory experiments provide experimental data to benchmark numerical simulations.

 

A 2015 NSF funded expedition to the Havre submarine volcano provided a new opportunity to study volcanic density currents. We showed how the mass and energy exchange between volcanic particles and their surroundings affects the dispersal of particles and the large scale dynamics of volcanic eruptions. Numerical models and laboratory experiments resolved a long-standing open question about why pumice floats so long but does eventually sink: we showed that pumice can trap gas, but diffusion ultimately allows this gas to be lost.

 

One student completed a PhD dissertation and four undergraduate students contributed to this research project. Ten refereed publications were published, in press or submitted.
